title: How can I dissolve a small business to protect myself from our creditors?
question: I have an artisan food company and we have run out of cash. We are buried in overhead expenses relating to a failed retail outlet and scaling our manufacturing capabilities ( equipment leases )
question_tags: Child support,Sole proprietorship,Business debt,Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Business
answers:
As already answered by other attorneys, you don't list whether you are incorporated or a sole proprietorship, and even if incorporated, if you are already liable for debts you cannot afford as a result of contracts, personal guarantees, or what is called "piercing the corporate veil" to establish personal liability. Pay an attorney in CA to find out those options is my advise. We charge corporations for such advice, but not individuals for reasons beyond this forum. But if you file bankruptcy, other issues and facts can affect your case so I will point some of those out next for you too.

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an
attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping
everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the
exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523
(Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and
presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so
you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!
Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your
state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but
your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity
thereof!
Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your
options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you
have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply
with your attorney too.
But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a
relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that
relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the
bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so
meet with one no matter what.
Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one
as soon as you can.
You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now
and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

"Closing the business" may not resolve your financial issues if you were the personal guarantor of the business debts. More information is needed to give you useful advice. Click the Avvo tab "Find a lawyer". You may be surprised how affordable a personal bankruptcy will be.

If the business is a corporation, beware because dissolving an insolvent corporation will make the shareholders liable for debts that were solely corporate debts.

The cost of a bankruptcy, if one is needed, is probably going to be a lot less than you are expecting. Don't assume you can't afford the fees.

Closing the company is far easier than dealing with the aftermath. Stop ordering inventory, close the doors and make sure your taxes are paid. Then comes the hard part. The first question is whether the company is a proprietorship or a corporation. Assuming a corporation, the next question is are there any assets which could be used to pay creditors, and how that would be accomplished. The answer to that question would determine if the corporation should file a bankruptcy.
The next question is for what debt you may be personally liable, that would determine your personal options.
You asked this under chapter 11, which is a business reorganization. You or the company would probably be more likely to file a chapter 7. Call around. Most experienced bankruptcy counsel will offer an initial consultation to determine your options and if a corporate or personal case would be advisable.

Is your business a corporation, or a sole proprietorship? If a corporation, the California Secretary of State website has instructions on how to dissolve a corporation. Then the question is, are your personally liable for those business debts? If your business is a sole proprietorship, you are personally liable for those debts. If you're personally liable for those debts, you probably should do a bankruptcy. In any event, do yourself a big favor and get a consultation (many are free) with an experienced bankruptcy attorney to see what your options are.
